intro: Lepidium corsicum, commonly known as Corsican peppergrass, is a flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, which includes many other well-known plants such as cabbages and mustards. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and is characterized by its small, yellow flowers and pinnately divided leaves. It produces small, round, green or black seeds that are dispersed by wind. Lepidium corsicum is often found in coastal areas and can thrive in harsh, saline environments.
